title: Mardersteig
content:
Hi,

has anyone seen the exhibition about Mardersteig, i.e. the work of the Stamperia Valdonega,  
before the opening of the book fair in Leipzig?

I feel boring and wondering if anyone wants to speak about it..

Stefan

comments.content:
Hi Stefan,

I’m planning to go there next week.  
The exhibition will last until end of June. The [website of the Druckkunst-Museum](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905131032/http:/www.druckkunst-museum.de/) has [more information](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905131032/http:/www.druckkunst-museum.de/de/ausstellung_aktuell.html).  
F
Florian: how was it? Did you manage to take any pictures?

Antonio: Yes, I’ve been there and I also could take a few pictures:  
 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hardwig/sets/72157604550248279/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905131032/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/hardwig/sets/72157604550248279/ "http://www.flickr.com/photos/hardwig/sets/72157604550248279/")

A visit to the Museum für Druckkunst in Leipzig pays, anyway. And the Mardersteig exhibition is really very impressive. If you have the opportunity, I strongly advise you to go there.

Alas, the photos hardly convey the ambiance that emanates from the numerous exhibits. As I couldn’t really capture the books’ formidable spirit, I just picked a couple of interesting details.

By the way: the [accompanying catalogue](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905131032/http:/hsl.chalco.net/erez4/fsi4/fsi.swf?pages_server=http://hsl.chalco.net/erez4&pages_dir=FSI%5FPages/hyphen/Demo/grafiche%20SIZ/LIPSIA/&cfg=pages_presets/catalog.fsi&Skin=plain&pages_pagecolor=000000&pages_slider=0&pages_index=1&MouseModes_Mode2=0&pages_skin=plain&pages_pagebordercolor=999999&pages_menu=1&pages_BendEffect=none) is online at the [Stamperia Valdonega website](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905131032/http:/www.stamperiavaldonega.it/), as a Flash file that can be searched, browsed and zoomed.

Nice pictures Florian!

Did you enjoy the exhibiton?

Stefan
Stefan: yes, I did. Only, it’s a pity that you can’t touch the books and browse through their pages. They all are behind glass (of course).

Yes, I understand.  
But if you are really interested, you may get in touch directly with Mardersteig.  
Maybe he will show you something, to touch also. ;-)  
I you want I can ask him.  
And by the way: Verona is always worth a journey for it’s definitely the most beautiful city in the world!

wishes  
Stefan
